Data

  • How we got here
  • Problems in data
  • Where does the future lead?
  • Examples and Code

How we got here

When we collect information, we do so in a number of ways. Standardizing the methods we use for data gathering over time has allowed us to compare and show relationships over time and the changes in variables.

Science has been an early user of data. It allowed evidence to be promoted and compared with other sources.

Problems in data

With decreasing costs, it is becoming increasingly feasible to add sensors, objects which can collect information, to everything. On one hand this could make everything “smarter”, but in another, it creates a lot of mess.

Hardware runs on chips which contain vulnerabilities, therefore, as more and more devices and items in our everyday lives produce more data to tell us more, we have to be aware that we open ourselves our to having our data compromised (re: stolen).

Where does the future lead?

We will see more streams of data. Meaning the data never stops–it’s not static. This is important to understand because it means the feedback loop for many things will be much shorter.

The job of the future data visualizer will be dealing with this firehose and figuring out which parts are important in real time.

Examples and Code

D3.js

Site: d3js.org

Github: github.com/mbostock/d3

D3.js is the visualization library behind many of today’s interactive visualization. It allows for deep control over all final interactions, but is also used as a building block for a number of other data tools.

  • Tutorials
    • code.minnpost.com/simple-map-d3/
    • Dashing D3.js ebook
    • Official D3.js list of tutorials
  • Examples
    • How Obama Won Re-election
    • Racing Against History

Raphael.js

Site: raphaeljs.com

Github: github.com/DmitryBaranovskiy/raphael

Raphael and D3 are often substitutable. Raphael, while not as complete of a interactive library, allows easy building of charts and graphs.

  • Tutorials
    • An introduction to Raphael JS library, Tutsplus+
    • Intro to Raphael, HTML5 Rocks
    • Raphael JS tutorial part I
    • Using Raphael with SVGs
    • Create a responsive and interactive animation with Raphael.js
    • VIDEO: Raphael Part I Raphael Part II
  • Examples
    • Canada map and data
    • Easing with Raphael.js

Kimono

Site: KimonoLabs.com

Github: github.com/kimonolabs

Kimono’s acts as the database and scraper. Kimono has a powerful user interface to select parts of a web page, that you can then set to scrape at certain intervals. Kimono then gives you access to the database in a static JSON file to work with.

  • Tutorials
    • Interactive: Create your first API
    • Web scraping with Kimono Labs
    • Video: Using Kimono

Chart.js

Site: chartjs.org

Github: github.com/nnnick/Chart.js

Chart.js is a library for getting charts up and running quickly. The goal of the library is making beautiful charts simple to make.

  • Tutorials
    • Build a dynamic dashboard with ChartJS
    • Create animated charts with Chart.JS
    • Getting started with Chart.js
  • Examples
    • Thing1

Chartbuilder

Site: quartz.github.io/Chartbuilder

Github: github.com/Quartz/Chartbuilder

Chartbuilder is an interface that makes it easy for anyone to type in some data and get a chart. This makes Chartbuilder one of the quickest ways to get a chart if you already have your data ready to go.

  • Tutorial
    • How to turn everyone in your newsroom into graphics editors with Chartbuilder
    • How to use Chartbuilder to make simple graphics fast
  • Examples
    • Water cleanup commences, New Hampshire Public Radio
    • Bike Sales in Europe, NPR
    • Small business still reeling from credit crunch

Sheetsee.js

Site: jlord.us/sheetsee.js

Github: github.com/jlord/sheetsee.js

Sheetsee.js works together with Google Spreadsheets to allow you to connect a spreadsheet of data into charts and maps interactives.

  • Tutorial
    • About sheetsee.js
    • Shetsee.js: the basics
    • Jessica Lord on Sheetsee.js
  • Examples
    • Mapping hack spots
    • Budget visualization

Tabletop.js

Github: github.com/jsoma/tabletop

Like Sheetsee.js, Tabletop.js also using Google Spreadsheets as the database and then connects your page to allow for data to be connected to your interactive visuals.

  • Tutorial
    • Tabletop.js’s Github README
    • Why I don’t use Tabletop.js in production
    • Using spreadsheets and Tabletop.js as a Web App Backend
    • Web-based data tables with Tabletop.js
    • Creating a styled data project with Tabletop and Handlebars
  • Examples
    • Internet Indians, Al Jazeera
    • Mayor Tracker 2013, WNYC
    • Mapsheet
    • You Might Be the 47 Percent If…, Mother Jones
    • Police Departments, Massachusetts
    • Mother Jones News Quiz

Fusion Tables

Site: support.google.com/fusiontables/answer/2571232

Fusion Tables is Google’s tool that integrates with Spreadsheets to make creating visualizations simple.

  • Tutorials
    • Google’s Fusion Tables tutorials
    • Mountain Bike trails
    • Mapping population densities by the block
    • Mapping with Fusion Tables
    • Video: Google Fusion Table map visualization tutorial
  • Examples
    • Mapping the riots with poverty, Guardian
    • Newspaper Map
    • What’s the most congested street in Toronto, Globe and Mail
    • Hurricane zones, WNYC
